conclusion: Determine how much the point light source S should be moved vertically upward so that the light emitted from S is just not visible above the water surface.
The light source S is initially at a depth H = sqrt(3)r.
The refractive index of the liquid is n = sqrt(2).
The light must be refracted at the critical angle to be just not visible above the water surface.
Calculate the critical angle theta_c using sin(theta_c) = 1/n = 1/sqrt(2) = sqrt(2)/2, therefore theta_c = 45 degrees.
When the light is refracted at the critical angle, it travels along the edge of the circle of radius r on the surface.
The light path forms a right triangle with the vertical distance from S to the surface and the radius r.
The vertical distance from S to the surface is H - x, where x is the distance S is moved upward, and the horizontal distance is r. Using tan(45 degrees) = 1 = r/(H - x), therefore r = H - x.
Substitute H = sqrt(3)r into r = sqrt(3)r - x, rearrange to solve for x: x = sqrt(3)r - r = (sqrt(3) - 1)r.
The point source S should be moved vertically upward by a distance of (sqrt(3) - 1)r.
